Description.val:
This line item funds Common Electronic Countermeasures (ECM) equipment for strike and assault aircraft.  The overall goal of the modification budget is to provide a reprogrammable radar and missile warning system, provide attacking missile declaration, sector direction finding, laser detection, and self-protection capability devices to applicable user aircraft.

Operational Safety Improvements Program (OSIP) 014-90 AN/APR-39(V)2 Radar Warning Receiver (RWR): The AN/APR-39A/B/C/D (V) 2 Radar Signal Detecting Set is designed for United States Marine Corps (USMC), United States Navy (USN), United States Air Force (USAF), and United States Army (US Army) Assault Support aircraft to provide onboard situational awareness and warning of radar threats. NRE, integration, validation/ verification and procurement of the upgraded APR-39 system (APR-39D (V)2) will continue through FY 2031. 

OSIP 006-00 ALE-39 to ALE-47 Retrofit: This OSIP provides funding for retrofit installation of AN/ALE-47 on F/A-18/C/D aircraft lots 12-17 and to procure new AN/ALE-47 Test Sets (ALM-290) to replace original version ALM-286s. The replacement of the AN/ALE-39 Dispenser system with the AN/ALE-47 will correct serious safety problems and greatly improve aircraft survivability.

OSIP 005-08 Direct Infrared Countermeasure (DIRCM) / Department of Navy Large Aircraft Infrared Countermeasure (DoN LAIRCM) AN/AAQ-24: This OSIP provides current available technology improvements for survivability to United States Marine Corps aircraft.  This budget supports procurement, Engineering Change Proposals (ECPs), integration, validation, Follow-on Test and Evaluation (FOT&E) and fielding of DoN LAIRCM systems on CH-53E/K, KC-130J, P-8A and MV-22 platforms.

OSIP 004-12 Common On-Board Jammer: Integrated Defensive Electronic Counter Measure (IDECM) Block 4 is an ECP to the ALQ-214 intended to render it suitable for operation on the F/A-18C/D aircraft, while retaining all IDECM suite functionality when installed on F/A-18E/F aircraft. The Electronic Frequency Converter (EFC) enables dataflow via the fiber optic cable to the Fiber Optic Towed Decoy (FOTD) and is part of the IB-4 configuration when installed on the F/A-18E/F aircraft. This OSIP is for the onboard portion of the IB-4 configuration. 

OSIP 017-12 Correction of Discrepancies: This OSIP will provide the required correction to multiple sub-components that are obsolete.

OSIP 004-15 Assault Correction of Discrepancies: Assault of Corrections of Discrepancies OSIP will affect changes to assault Electronic Countermeasure (ECM) equipment in the aircraft that have been delivered for fleet operations. These ECM systems require various upgrade initiatives to keep these aircraft mission capable with a robust defensive system that ensure aircraft survivability.

OSIP 018-17 Assault Direct Infrared Countermeasures (ADIRCM): This OSIP provides funding for the installation of Assault Direct Infrared Countermeasures on the United States Navy/United States Marine Corps chosen material solution for AH-1Z, UH-1Y, and MH-60S aircraft in response to Joint Urgent Operational Needs Statement (SO-0010).

Justification.val:
FY19 Baseline funding is required for Common Electronic Countermeasures (ECM) equipment for strike and assault aircraft.

OCO: 
FY19 OCO is required for the following:

OSIP 018-17 Assault Direct Infrared Countermeasures (ADIRCM): FY 2019 OCO funds are required to procure assets in support of fielding the next Marine Expeditionary Unit (MEU). The FY 2019 OCO ensures that the capability to conduct missions in areas where the JUONS threat exists until the Program of Record (PoR) assets can be fielded.

Model.val: UH-1Y, AH-1Z, MV-22,  KC-130T, CH-53E/K, KC-130J, MH-53, HH-60H, MH-60S

Name.@footnote: 2.14) Other support increases due to inflation.

1.1.1) Quantiles decreased in FY 2018 - 2023 to reflect escalated actual unit cost pricing in contract options.  Price difference between V-22 and H-1 is because V22 requires two additional receivers.  Cost to complete quantities increased due to adding UH-1Y.
1.1.2) Quantiles decreased in FY 2018 - 2023 to reflect escalated actual unit cost pricing in contract options  Price difference between V-22 and H-1 is because V22 requires two additional receivers.

Name.val: 1.1.3) Install Equipment Conversion B Kits - Organic

Description.val:
DESCRIPTION / JUSTIFICATION:  The AN/APR-39A/B/C/D(V)2 Radar Signal Detecting Set is designed for United States Marine Corps (USMC), United States Navy (USN), United States Air Force (USAF) and United States Army (US Army) Assault Support aircraft to provide onboard situational awareness and warning of radar threats by Statement of Operational Requirements Document (ORD) number 545-88-00 dated 14 February 2000. The AN/APR-39A/B/C/D(V)2 also provides control and display of the AAR-47 Missile Warning System and Chaff dispense commands to the ALE-47 Counter Measure Dispensing System. The AN/APR-39C/D(V)2 provides control and display of the AAQ-24 and AAR-59. The APR-39A/B/C/D(V)2 consists of five antennas, one Cockpit Control unit, a display, two, three, or four receivers (dependent on a/c configuration) and one processor. This OSIP supports the following: Class I Engineering Change Proposal (ECP), APR-39D(V)2, that corrects Part I deficiencies against the Radar Warning Receiver (RWR) noted in AH-1W, MV-22 and KC-130T Operational Evaluation (OpEval) reports; C(V)2 and D(V)2 software upgrade; and interface/integrations to include Integrated Aircraft Survivability Equipment.  Updates required through the Future Year Defense Program (FYDP) for various platforms.  The current RWR APR-39 A/B/C provides inaccurate direction of arrival information, time delayed detection and identification of threat emitters causing loss of situational awareness to combat aircrews. The APR-39D(V)2 system will be the RWR solution for all assault support aircraft MV-22, AH-1, H-60, UH-1, H-53 and C-130.  

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES: The APR-39 is in the production and sustainment phase (MSIII3Q/96). The Department of Navy is the lead service of this joint service program. Non-Recurring Engineering (NRE), integration, validation/ verification and procurement of the upgraded APR-39 system (APR-39D(V)2) will continue through FY 2031.

Model.val: CH-53E, EA-6B,UH-1N, MH-53E, F/A-18C/D, AV-8B, MV-22, KC-130F/R/T, H-60, P-3

Name.@footnote: 3.6) F/A-18 ALM-290 Test Sets: FY 2019 cost increase for the ALM-290 test sets is due to implementation of AFC-566 which increases ALE-47 O-Level maintenance test equipment allowances per squadron, requiring additional quantity procurement. In addition, ALM-290 unit cost increase of the ALM-290s is due to redesign for miscellaneous components obsolescence.

3.12) Other Support:  FY 2018 cost increase is due to engineering and logistics support costs required technical oversight in production of kit components, conducting engineering analysis of issues identified during component acceptance, and updates to drawings as required.

1.1.2) F/A-18 A-Kit:   During FY 2017 thru FY 2019 A-kits are being procured for F/A-18C 2-dispenser, F/A-18D 2-dispenser, and F/A-18D 4-dispenser configurations.  The A-kit components and unit costs vary, depending on which type, model, series (TMS) being modified and quantity of dispensers (2 or 4 each) per TMS.  The FY 2019 cost increase is driven by additional F/A-18Ds becoming available for Air Frame Change (AFC)-566, which requires (4) dispensers and requires increased hours to complete modification.  Commander, Naval Air Forces (CNAF) is continuing extension of flight hours and service life on the F/A-18s, possibly to FY 2031, to fill strike fighter shortfall, requiring (49) additional aircraft modifications.  FY 2019 funds (25) F/A-18 A-kits, leaving a Cost-to-Complete quantity of (24) for the planned aircraft modifications to accommodate F/A-18 aircraft with extended service life.

2.1.2) F/A-18 B Kits:  FY 2019 B-Kit cost increase is due to procurement of new B-kit components (where in previous years some B-kit components were reused or reconditioned from retiring aircraft with ALE-47 installed). B-kit unit cost and the number of components vary depending on the T/M/S receiving the modification; some "D" model aircrafts have (4) dispensers vice (2) for "C" model.    The Technical Directive for AFC-566 was approved to allow for stand-alone modifications, which will provide increased schedule flexibility ALE-47 Retrofit aircraft induction without schedule delays of concurrent aircraft modifications.  Based on CNAF continuing extension of flight hours and service life on the F/A-18s, possibly to FY 2031, to fill strike fighter shortfall.  FY 2019 funds (25) F/A-18 B-kits, leaving a Cost-To-Complete quantity of (24) for the planned aircraft modifications to accommodate F/A-18 aircraft with extended service life.

ImplementationMethodName.val: Depot Level Installation:: Installation Name: F/A-18C Installation Costs

Description.val:
DESCRIPTION/JUSTIFICATION:  The replacement of the AN/ALE-39 Dispenser System with the AN/ALE-47 will correct serious safety problems and greatly improve aircraft survivability. As a joint program, Under Secretary of Defense (Acquisition Technology & Logistics) memo of November 1986 directed the United States Navy (USN) and United States Army (US Army) to participate in the United States Air Force (USAF) Engineering Manufacturing Development (EMD) phase. 

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:  The AN/ALE-47 system is in production and being installed in multiple USN, USMC and USAF aircraft. This OSIP provides funding for retrofit installation of AN/ALE-47 on F/A-18/C/D aircraft lots 12-17 and to procure new AN/ALE-47 Test Sets (ALM-290) to replace original version ALM-286s.

Name.@footnote: 2.6)  FY18 Support Equipment and ILS cost increased due to additional A/C Integration NRE efforts and increased MEU & SPMAGTF deployment sites requiring additional support equipment.

1.1.2) FY21: MV-22 Total Quantity initially assumed 1/3 of MV-22s would receive GLTAs (completed in 2021); remaining would be procured without GLTA(PMA275 to determine final configuration).  FY20 thru FY23 DON LAIRCM unit cost varies based on platform configuration (WRA qty) and combined procurements for other customers.  Utilization of Other Customer Funds enabled a decrease in Cost to Complete.
1.1.3) DON LAIRCM unit cost varies based on platform configuration (WRA qty) and combined procurements for other customers.

1.2.1)  FY18 A/C Integration NRE cost increased due to Processor Upgrade requirements.  We reduced FY18 B-Kit (1.1.1) by four systems and reduced S/W Upgrade (2.3); funds were re-aligned to support A/C Integration NRE (Processor Upgrade).

Name.val: 1.2.3) Archived B Kits Non Recurring - Organic

Description.val:
DESCRIPTION/JUSTIFICATION: The AN/AAQ-24 Department of the Navy, Large Aircraft Infrared Countermeasures (DoN LAIRCM) System (B-kit) consists of 5 components: Missile Warning Sensor (MWS, 5 or 6), processor (1), Guardian Laser Transmitter Assembly (GLTA, 2) and Controller Interface Unit (CIU)(1). The Defense Intelligence Agency (DIA) System Threat Assessment Report (STAR) and current United States Marine Corps (USMC) operations pose surface to air threats requiring DoN LAIRCM capabilities to maintain survivability against improved Man-Portable Air Defense Systems (MANPADS), Rocket Propelled Grenades (RPG), hostile gunfire, Anti-Aircraft Artillery (AAA) and laser-directed weapons.  This budget supports procurement, Engineering Change Proposals (ECPs), integration, validation, Follow-on Test and Evaluation (FOT&E) and fielding of DoN LAIRCM systems on CH-53E/K, KC-130J, P-8A and MV-22 platforms in accordance with Statement of Operational Requirement Document (ORD) number 756-88-08. Based on FY 2015 Joint Urgent Operational Needs Statement (JUONS) SO-0010, United States Special Operations Command (SOCOM) and United States of America (USA) programs have approved requirements for DoN LAIRCM integration.  FY18 A/C Integration NRE cost increased due to Processor Upgrade requirements.  We reduced FY18 B-Kit by four systems and reduced S/W Upgrade; funds were re-aligned to support A/C Integration NRE (Processor Upgrade).

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES: DoN LAIRCM program achieved Milestone C / Full-Rate Production (FRP) in January 2010. The Engineering Change Proposals (ECPs) provide required improvements and address identified deficiencies (e.g. Advanced Threat Warning (ATW), to improve Missile Warning Sensor (MWS) detection (Probability detection (Pd)), lowered False Alarm Rate (FAR), threat information for Smart Dispensing, Hostile Fire Indication (HFI) and Laser Warning (LW)).  FY 2017 OCO procured 12 DoN LAIRCM (AN/AAQ-24) B-kits with Advanced Threat Warning (ATW) sensor capabilities for KC-130J aircraft and 12 DoN LAIRCM (AN/AAQ-24) B-kits with Advanced Threat Warning (ATW) sensor capabilities for MV-22 aircraft.  FY 2018 OCO procures 12  DoN LAIRCM (AN/AAQ-24) B-kits with Advanced Threat Warning (ATW) sensor capabilities for MV-22 aircraft supporting SPMAGTF.

Name.@footnote: ALQ-214 Other Support: Funding supports annual ALQ-214 Repair and Field Support Contract as well as Program and Engineering Support.

Name.val: 1.1.1) Archived B Kits Install Equipment - Organic

Name.@footnote: ALQ-214 Retrofit Kits (E/F) Install Equipment: FY 2018 additional ALQ-214 E/F Retrofit kits procured to correlate to additional aircraft procured by PMA-265. Retrofit kits procured through FY 2018 to support operational deployments with the Block 4 Capability.
Name.val: 1.1.2) ALQ-214 Retrofit Kits (E/F) Install Equipment - Organic

Name.@footnote: ALQ-214 Installation Equipment quantity increase due to reduced unit pricing achieved by leveraging economies of scale via FMS/NAVSUP/PMA-265 systems that are purchased in addition to the PMA-272 budgeted quantities.  This unit cost reduction in FY 2017 through the FYDP enables the program to complete 2 years earlier than planned.

Description.val:
DESCRIPTION/JUSTIFICATION:  Integrated Defensive Electronic Countermeasure (IDECM) Block (IB-4)  is an Engineering Change Proposal (ECP) to the ALQ-214 intended to render it suitable for operation on the F/A-18C/D aircraft equipped with ALR-67(V)2 or ALR-67(V)3 Radar Warning Receivers, while retaining all IDECM suite functionality when installed on F/A-18E/F aircraft. This ECP will result in a Common On-Board Jammer (COBJ) system that must meet the requirements of the COBJ Block 2 Operational Requirements Document (ORD) #624-78-03 and be compatible with the ALE-55 Fiber Optic Towed Decoy (FOTD). The Electronic Frequency Converter (EFC) enables dataflow via the fiber optic cable to the FOTD and is part of the IB-4 configuration when installed on the F/A-18E/F aircraft. This Operational Safety Improvement Program (OSIP) is for the onboard portion of the IB-4 configuration.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES: The ALQ-214 received Milestone III approval in January 2004 and is still in Full-Rate Production (FRP). FRP 9 was the first ALQ-214 production lot in the IB-4 configuration and was awarded 3rd Qtr FY 2012. Annual production contract awards are expected to continue through FY 2027. A total of 324 IB-4 ALQ-214s are planned for procurement.

Name.@footnote: 3.6) Other Support in FY 2017 supports RR-2055 Special Receiver procurement receipt and modification.

Name.val: 1.1.2) RR-2055 Special Receiver ECP- TBD - Organic

Description.val:
DESCRIPTION/JUSTIFICATION: This Operational Safety Improvement Program (OSIP) is for the correction of discrepancies and to effect changes to ALR-67(V)2 system and electronic countermeasure equipment in aircraft that have been delivered for fleet operations. This system requires various upgrade initiative and logistic support to keep the F/A-18 a capable aircraft with a robust defensive system that improves its survivability. This OSIP will provide funding for the upgrade of the ALR-67(V)2 computer, low band antenna, special receiver and quadrant receiver weapons replaceable assemblies.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES: Developed Preliminary Design Review (PDR) for Program Control Unit (PCU)1 drawing package and prototype Circuit Card Assemblies (CCA), and performed Critical Design Review (CDR), conducted system testing, evaluations, environmental and qualification testing, modify Shop Replaceable Assemblies (SRA) with Diminished Manufacturing Source (DMS) issued and developed Acceptance Test Plans (ATP) and Engineering Change Proposals (ECP) and verified testing and evaluations of new designs. The United States Navy (USN) Fleet Support Team provide system engineering qualification on aircraft, support equipment and develop technical directives and any additional Integrated Logistics Support (ILS) requirements. The USN and contractor software support activities develops software integrations.

Name.@footnote: 2.1.2 Infrared Sources:  Common Electronic Countermeasure (ECM) equipment is made up of multiple components for strike and assault aircraft protection systems.

Description.val:
DESCRIPTION/JUSTIFICATION: This Operational Safety Improvement Program (OSIP) is for the correction of discrepancies to affect changes to assault Electronic Countermeasure (ECM) equipment in aircraft that have been delivered for fleet operations. These ECM systems require various upgrade initiatives and logistic support to keep these aircraft mission capable with a robust defensive system that ensures its survivability. 

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES: The contract will modify shop replaceable assemblies with diminished manufacturing source issues and conduct engineering change proposals, and verify testing and evaluations of modification designs. The United States Navy Fleet Support Team will provide system engineering qualifications on aircraft, support equipment, write technical directives, upgrade technical data and perform any additional integrated logistics support requirements. United States Navy and contractor software support activities will integrate software as needed.

Name.@footnote: 3.1) OCO Other Support: FY 2018 increases as the program transitions from development to PoR.  Other support includes Government Teams supporting procurement of assets, project management, engineering support for initial B-kit fielding as well as product support.
(1) 1.1.3 Unit cost increase due to procurement of only 6 systems in FY19 vice 24 in FY18

Description.val:
Description:  Assault Directed Infrared Countermeasure (ADIRCM) is the budget name for DAIRCM which is a lightweight Threat Warning System (TWS) and Infrared Countermeasure (IRCM) developed by the Navy Research Lab under an FY 2004 Office of Naval Research Future Naval Capability (FN04-03), Integrated E/O IR Self-Protect Suite for Rotary Wing Aircraft.  PMA272 has funded this Future Naval Capability (FNC) since 2006 as a risk mitigation for both the Joint and Allied Threat Awareness System (JATAS) and the Common Infrared Countermeasures (CIRCM) system. The DAIRCM nomenclature is the AAQ-45 System which offers significant savings in Size, Weight and Power (SWaP) and cost avoidance. The system consists of a centralized processor and laser with high power fiber optic cables leading to 4-6 two-color IR sensors. Each sensor incorporates a pointer tracker, which allows laser energy to be focused on incoming threats. 

FY 2017 through FY 2019 Overseas Contingency Operations (OCO) funds for AAQ-45 provides increased survivability against Man-Portable Air Defense Systems (MANPADS), Rocket Propelled Grenades (RPG), hostile gunfire, Anti-Aircraft Artillery (AAA) and laser-directed weapons for combat, assault rotary wing and fixed wing aircraft in theater. FY 2017 OCO funds completed the original Joint Urgent Operational Need Statement (JUONS) fielding requirements. FY 2018 OCO funds are required to procure assets in support of fielding two additional Marine Expeditionary Units (MEUs). The FY 2018 OCO ensures the capability to conduct missions in areas where the JUONS threat exists until the Program of Record (PoR) assets can be fielded. FY 2019 OCO funds are required to procure assets in support of fielding MH-60S on two additional MEU's.


Developmental efforts:  JUONS phase includes the Non-Recurring Engineering (NRE) required to develop integrate and test all hardware, software and firmware to field AAQ-45. Efforts will also include the manufacturing of AAQ-45 test articles, test bench fixtures, fleet representative hardware and system training. The driving requirements can be found in the classified JUONS SO-0010 and the classified Request for Initiation of Rapid Deployment Capability (RDC) process for an Advanced Threat Warning and Inexhaustible Infrared Countermeasure for Rotary Wing Aircraft (RDC Ser N9/16S139158).   Two prime contractors, DRS and Daylight Solutions were awarded sole source contracts for the AAQ-45 Weapons Replaceable Assemblies (WRA).  During the JUONS phase, the AAQ-45 system will be installed on the following United States Navy (USN)/United States Marine Corps (USMC) aircraft identified in JUONS SO-0010:  AH-1Z, UH-1Y, and MH-60S. The AAQ-45 configuration on these aircraft will include one processor, one laser and four sensors. The USN's MH-60S is the lead platform for AAQ-45 JUONS configuration.
